an8.14:4.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you about eight wild colts and eight flaws in horses, and about eight wild people and eight flaws in people.
an8.14:4.2: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
an8.14:5.1: “And what, mendicants, are the eight wild colts and eight flaws in horses?
an8.14:5.2: Firstly, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts back right up and spin the chariot behind them.
an8.14:5.3: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:5.4: This is the first flaw of a horse.
an8.14:6.1: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.
an8.14:6.2: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:6.3: This is the second flaw of a horse.
an8.14:7.1: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.
an8.14:7.2: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:7.3: This is the third flaw of a horse.
an8.14:8.1: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.
an8.14:8.2: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:8.3: This is the fourth flaw of a horse.
an8.14:9.1: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.
an8.14:9.2: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:9.3: This is the fifth flaw of a horse.
an8.14:10.1: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts ignore the trainer and the goad, spit out the bit, and go wherever they want.
an8.14:10.2: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:10.3: This is the sixth flaw of a horse.
an8.14:11.1: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts don’t go forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.
an8.14:11.2: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:11.3: This is the seventh flaw of a horse.
an8.14:12.1: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.
an8.14:12.2: Some wild colts are like that.
an8.14:12.3: This is the eighth flaw of a horse.
an8.14:12.4: These are the eight wild colts and the eight flaws in horses.
an8.14:13.1: And what are the eight wild people and eight flaws in people?
an8.14:13.2: Firstly, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:13.3: But the accused mendicant evades it by saying they don’t remember.
an8.14:13.4: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, back right up and spin the chariot behind them.
an8.14:13.6: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:13.7: This is the first flaw of a person.
an8.14:14.1: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:14.2: But the accused mendicant objects to the accuser:
an8.14:14.3: ‘What’s an incompetent fool like you got to say?
an8.14:14.4: How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!’
an8.14:14.5: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.
an8.14:14.7: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:14.8: This is the second flaw of a person.
an8.14:15.1: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:15.2: But the accused mendicant retorts to the accuser:
an8.14:15.3: ‘Well, you’ve fallen into such-and-such an offence. You should deal with that first.’
an8.14:15.4: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.
an8.14:15.6: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:15.7: This is the third flaw of a person.
an8.14:16.1: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:16.2: But the accused mendicant dodges the issue, distracts the discussion with irrelevant points, and displays irritation, hate, and bitterness.
an8.14:16.3: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.
an8.14:16.5: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:16.6: This is the fourth flaw of a person.
an8.14:17.1: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:17.2: But the accused mendicant gesticulates while speaking in the middle of the Saṅgha.
an8.14:17.3: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.
an8.14:17.5: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:17.6: This is the fifth flaw of a person.
an8.14:18.1: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:18.2: But the accused mendicant ignores the Saṅgha and the accusation and, though still guilty of the offence, goes wherever they want.
an8.14:18.3: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, ignore the trainer and the goad, spit out the bit, and go wherever they want.
an8.14:18.5: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:18.6: This is the sixth flaw of a person.
an8.14:19.1: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:19.2: But the accused mendicant neither confesses to the offence nor denies it, but frustrates the Saṅgha by staying silent.
an8.14:19.3: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, don’t go forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.
an8.14:19.5: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:19.6: This is the seventh flaw of a person.
an8.14:20.1: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offence.
an8.14:20.2: But the accused mendicant says this:
an8.14:20.3: ‘Why are you venerables making so much of an issue over me? Now I’ll abandon the training and return to a lesser life.’
an8.14:20.4: When he has abandoned the training, he says:
an8.14:20.6: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.
an8.14:20.8: Some wild people are like that.
an8.14:20.9: This is the eighth flaw of a person.
an8.14:20.10: These are the eight wild people and eight flaws in people.”
